channel.title: Hall of song: The 'Met,' 1883-1966
channel.description:
Documentary series on history of the Metropolitan Opera Company ("The Met") in its original home at Broadway and 39th Street in New York. "The Met" closed its old location on April 16, 1966. Series includes interviews and rare recordings of noted performers.

An online collection of early educational public radio content from the National Association of Educational Broadcasters (NAEB).

item.title: 1926 through 1932
item.description: 1926 -1932. The Depression brings almost complete financial disaster. Otto Kahn resigns from the Met's Board of Directors. Voices of Ezio Pinza, Grace Moore, Gladys Swarthout, Lily Pons are featured.
item.dc:creator: Cross, Milton, 1897-1975
item.dc:subject: Performing Arts

item.title: 1950 through 1951
item.description: 1950 -1951. Rudolf Bing assumes general manager at the Met. Cesare Siepi recalls his debut in Mr. Bing's first opening night.
item.dc:creator: Cross, Milton, 1897-1975
item.dc:subject: Performing Arts

item.description: 1918. This program presents the conclusion to the Rosa Ponselle interview.
item.dc:creator: Cross, Milton, 1897-1975
item.dc:subject: Performing Arts

item.title: 1937 through 1938
item.description: 1937 -1938. Erich Leinsdorf arrives to assist Artur Bodanzky with the German operas. Maestro Leinsdorf is interviewed.
item.dc:creator: Cross, Milton, 1897-1975
item.dc:subject: Performing Arts

item.title: 1925 through 1926
item.description: 1925 -1926. Lauritz Melchior, Heldentenor, is interviewed. First of two parts.
item.dc:creator: Cross, Milton, 1897-1975
item.dc:subject: Performing Arts

item.description: 1940. Russian basso Alexander Kipnis recalls his years at the old Metropolitan. He recalls how he discovered Kirsten Flagstad.
item.dc:creator: Cross, Milton, 1897-1975
item.dc:subject: Performing Arts

item.title: 1903 through 1907
item.description: 1903 -1907. The Conried Regime. The controversial Parsifal premiere and the scandalous Salome first night. Early influence of J.P. Morgan. Features Geraldine Farrar, Olive Fremstad, Otto Goritz.
item.dc:creator: Cross, Milton, 1897-1975
item.dc:subject: Performing Arts

item.title: 1923 through 1924
item.description: 1923 -1924. Karin Branzell, contralto, recalls her 20 year career at the Met.
item.dc:creator: Cross, Milton, 1897-1975
item.dc:subject: Performing Arts

item.title: 1934 through 1935
item.description: 1934 -1935. Helen Jepson, soprana, makes her debut. She is interviewed.
item.dc:creator: Cross, Milton, 1897-1975
item.dc:subject: Performing Arts

item.title: 1933 through 1935
item.description: 1933 -1935. Lotte Lehmann makes her long-awaited debut. She is interviewed about her career and describes her association with Lauritz Melchior, Maria Olszewaka, Richard Strauss, and Bruno Walter.
item.dc:creator: Cross, Milton, 1897-1975
item.dc:subject: Performing Arts

item.description: 1950. Hans Hotter, German basso, relates some of the experiences of his rather brief Metropolitan career.
item.dc:creator: Cross, Milton, 1897-1975
item.dc:subject: Performing Arts

item.title: 1925 through 1926
item.description: 1925 -1926. Conclusion of Melchior interview. Refer to previous entry for information.
item.dc:creator: Cross, Milton, 1897-1975
item.dc:subject: Performing Arts

item.title: 1913 through 1918
item.description: 1913 -1918. The great ticket scandal. The Toscanini furor. German opera is dismissed at outbreak of war. Voices of Giovanni Martinelli, Giuseppe De Luca, Claudia Muzio, Florence Easton.
item.dc:creator: Cross, Milton, 1897-1975
item.dc:subject: Performing Arts

item.description: 1907. Feodor Chaliapin, the Russian basso, makes his debut and immediately causes great controversy. His daughter, Tania Chaliapin, is interviewed about the difficulty her father had in adjusting to the United States.
item.dc:creator: Cross, Milton, 1897-1975
item.dc:subject: Performing Arts

item.title: 1921 through 1924
item.description: 1921 -1924. Filling the void left by Caruso's death. Geraldine Farrer leaves the Met. Wagner stages a comeback.
item.dc:creator: Cross, Milton, 1897-1975
item.dc:subject: Performing Arts

item.title: 1909 through 1913
item.description: 1909 -1913. Hammerstein, a competitor, is forced to sell out, leaving the Met supreme in New York. Puccini attends premiere of Fanciulla del West. Recordings by Bori, Margarete Matzenauer, Luisa Tetrazzini.
item.dc:creator: Cross, Milton, 1897-1975
item.dc:subject: Performing Arts

item.title: 1963 through 1964
item.description: 1963 -1964. Dame Alicia Markova is interviewed; she came to the Met to direct the ballet.
item.dc:creator: Cross, Milton, 1897-1975
item.dc:subject: Performing Arts

item.title: A long look back, part 1
item.description: A Long Look Back. First of two programs in which Giovanni Martinelli and Licia Albanese review much of the old Met's history. They recall their wonderful experiences in the old house.
item.dc:creator: Cross, Milton, 1897-1975
item.dc:subject: Performing Arts

item.title: 1939 through 1940
item.description: 1939 -1940. Helen Traubel, soprano, is interviewed about her career. She recalls the incident with Rudolf Bing that caused her to terminate her career.
item.dc:creator: Cross, Milton, 1897-1975
item.dc:subject: Performing Arts

item.title: 1938 through 1939
item.description: 1938 -1939. Rise Stevens' first appearance. In an interview she recalls her long career.
item.dc:creator: Cross, Milton, 1897-1975
item.dc:subject: Performing Arts

item.title: 1898 through 1903
item.description: 1898 -1903. Features Maurice Grau, Lilli Lehmann, Johanna Gadski, Ernestine Schumann-Heink, Antonio Scotti, Anton Van Rooy.
item.dc:creator: Cross, Milton, 1897-1975
item.dc:subject: Performing Arts

item.title: A long look back, part 2
item.description: This program presents the conclusion to the reminiscences by Licia Albanese and Giovanni Martinelli.
item.dc:creator: Cross, Milton, 1897-1975
item.dc:subject: Performing Arts

item.title: 1883: A new opera house is decreed
item.description: 1883: A new opera house is decreed.
item.dc:creator: Cross, Milton, 1897-1975
item.dc:subject: Performing Arts

item.title: 1907 through 1909
item.description: 1907 -1909. Beginning of Gatti's reign. Toscanini arrives. New talent: Emmy Destinn, Maria Gay, Frances Alda, Pasquale Amato, Adamo Didur.
item.dc:creator: Cross, Milton, 1897-1975
item.dc:subject: Performing Arts

item.description: 1903. Features Enrico Caruso, with reminiscences by Bruno Zirato, Rosa Ponselle, Giuseppe Bamboschek.
item.dc:creator: Cross, Milton, 1897-1975
item.dc:subject: Performing Arts

item.title: 1959 through 1960
item.description: 1959 -1960. Birgit Nilsson makes her debut and is interviewed.
item.dc:creator: Cross, Milton, 1897-1975
item.dc:subject: Performing Arts

item.title: 1893 through 1897
item.description: 1893 -1897. The House re-opens following a fire. Features recordings of Emma Calve', Pol Plancon, Nellie Melba, Francesco Tamagno.
item.dc:creator: Cross, Milton, 1897-1975
item.dc:subject: Performing Arts

item.description: 1918. Rosa Ponselle, the soprano, makes a sensational debut. In the first of a two-part interview she tells of her first seasons with the company.
item.dc:creator: Cross, Milton, 1897-1975
item.dc:subject: Performing Arts

item.title: The end of an era
item.description: The End of an Era. The last day of music at the old Met. Walter Slezak, son of tenor Leo Slezak, joins Milton Cross and Miles Kastendieck to give an account of the farewell concert, April 16, 1966.
item.dc:creator: Cross, Milton, 1897-1975
item.dc:subject: Performing Arts

item.description: 1913. Giuseppe Bamboschek arrives in New York to serve as company's musical secretary. In an interview he describes the difficult situations he encountered during the Gatti era.
item.dc:creator: Cross, Milton, 1897-1975
item.dc:subject: Performing Arts

item.description: 1940. Eleanor Steber, soprano, is interviewed.
item.dc:creator: Cross, Milton, 1897-1975
item.dc:subject: Performing Arts

item.title: 1920 through 1921
item.description: 1920 -1921. Tragedy strikes during a performance of Elisir d'Amore in Brooklyn and signals the end of Caruso's career. Rosa Ponselle, Giuseppe Bamboschek and Bruno Zirato recall his death.
item.dc:creator: Cross, Milton, 1897-1975
item.dc:subject: Performing Arts

item.title: 1932 through 1933
item.description: 1932 -1933. The Metropolitan Opera Association is formed. Soprana Frida Leider talks about her career in New York.
item.dc:creator: Cross, Milton, 1897-1975
item.dc:subject: Performing Arts

item.title: 1934 through 1937
item.description: 1934 -1937. Transition to Edward Johnson's managerial regime. Lucrezia Bori gives her farewell speech at her last performance. Kerstin Thorberg is interviewed.
item.dc:creator: Cross, Milton, 1897-1975
item.dc:subject: Performing Arts

item.description: 1945. Robert Merrill describes his career.
item.dc:creator: Cross, Milton, 1897-1975
item.dc:subject: Performing Arts

item.title: 1948 through 1949
item.description: 1948 -1949. Contralto Jean Madeira makes her debut. She is interviewed about her career.
item.dc:creator: Cross, Milton, 1897-1975
item.dc:subject: Performing Arts

item.title: 1941 through 1945
item.description: 1941 -1945. The war years and their effect on the Met. Dorothy Kirsten is interviewed about behind-the-scenes complications which take place during every opera season.
item.dc:creator: Cross, Milton, 1897-1975
item.dc:subject: Performing Arts

item.description: 1909. Leo Slezak, the outstanding tenor, arrives. His son Walter is interviewed about his life with "Pappa" at the old Met.
item.dc:creator: Cross, Milton, 1897-1975
item.dc:subject: Performing Arts

item.title: 1884 through 1892
item.description: 1884 -1892: The Wagnerian Tide. Features the voices of Lilli Lehmann, Lillian Nordica, Edouard de Reszke.
item.dc:creator: Cross, Milton, 1897-1975
item.dc:subject: Performing Arts
